PAD_HellishItems_02Skull.synopsis: Players AD after an Arcana check when they are inside the Diabolist House and see devilish objects.

SwD_Helsik.synopsis: Speak with Dead dialog for Helsik.
SwD_Helsik.how_to_trigger: Speak with S_LOW_DevilsFee_Helsik_299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597 with Speak with Dead after that character dies.

EmperorAD_FinishingRitual.synopsis: Emperor subbed AD when players activate the portal to go to House of Hope.
EmperorAD_FinishingRitual.how_to_trigger: On Devil's Fee, near the Circle of Invocation, S_LOW_DevilsFee_CircleOfInvocation_8841f33a-d17b-475e-848f-8f256407e7d0, when players put the items in the right place (check Devil's Fee QDD) they will activate the following flag: LOW_DevilsFee_Event_OpeningPortal_4dfbe814-2457-40ae-bead-b997d0724af2Setting that flag will start this AD. Alternatively, you can set that flag using ReCon.

AD_PatrolInOrder.synopsis: If, at the end of his patrolling, Helsik finds everything in order, this AD will be triggered.
AD_PatrolInOrder.how_to_trigger: Is one of the behaviours of S_LOW_DevilsFee_Helsik_299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597.

PAD_HellishItems_03Gems.synopsis: Players AD after an Arcana check when they are inside the Diabolist House and see devilish objects.

AD_HelsikBeforeCombat.synopsis: If players attack Helsik outside the main dialog and begin combat, Helsik will yell this.
AD_HelsikBeforeCombat.how_to_trigger: Starting combat with S_LOW_DevilsFee_Helsik_299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597 outside the main dialog (attacking her, stealing from ther or something like that).

PAD_HellishItems_04Horns.synopsis: Players AD after an Arcana check when they are inside the Diabolist House and see devilish objects.

EmperorAD_EnterRitualChamber.synopsis: Emperor AD if players agree to go to House of Hope against their advice.
EmperorAD_EnterRitualChamber.how_to_trigger: Get the grimmoire to go to House of Hope and go upstairs Devil's Fee. - Anchor: S_LOW_DevilsFee_RitualCicleScene_f193dbba-450b-41e5-90d3-7db09f7c9faf

PAD_HellishItems_Bones01.synopsis: Players AD after an Arcana check when they are inside the Diabolist House and see devilish objects.

PAD_FirstSeeCircleInvocation.synopsis: When player enter for the first time at the Invocation Circle before knowing about the ritual to go to House of Hope, the character will say this PAD.

PAD_ItemsInInvocationRoom.synopsis: When players pick the Coin of Mammon or the Infernal Marble before knowing that Helsik is a Diabolist, they will know that the "curio shop" is more than they thought. This will unlock the option to ask Helsik about the hellish items.
PAD_ItemsInInvocationRoom.how_to_trigger: Make click on S_LOW_DevilsFee_InfernalMarble_c8e18f16-4377-4e51-9790-fbff74510814 or S_LOW_DevilsFee_CoinOfMammon_8378143d-07de-4fca-881a-cb9791ac2f1c before the flag LOW_DevilsFee_Know_NoticeHellishItems_b0cfc46c-4730-26f1-f3a2-a6d7147a5e58 is set.

Helsik.synopsis:
Default dialogue with Helsik. They are a trader and warlock in lower city. They grant us the ingredients to perform the ritual to the House of Hope. 

HELPFUL DEBUG COMMANDS:
oe LOW_GetItemsFromGortash - learn about Helsik from Gortash's note
oe LOW_KnowAllHelsik - learn that Helsik is a diabolist and that they know the way to the HoH
oe LOW_PortalHouseOfHope - set up the interactable HoH portal without having to do the ritual
Helsik.how_to_trigger: Making click on S_LOW_Helsik 299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597 at the Diabolist House.

PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee.synopsis: VB when players are in the street near Devil's Fee (the diabolist house). Karlack will start this VB.
PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee.how_to_trigger: Entering S_LOW_DevilsFee_VB_ArrivingDevilsFee_508b0ddc-9d86-4b46-b75e-86c3ff60c827 with Karlach in the party.

RitualCircle.synopsis: Dialog to invoke the ritual to go to House of Hope from Lower City.RELEVANT NOTE: This dialog will only appear at the first time players go to house of hope. Later, this never will be triggered again.

AD_PatrolNotInOrder.synopsis: If, at the end of his patrolling, Helsik finds that somethis was stolen,
AD_PatrolNotInOrder.how_to_trigger: Is one of the behaviours of S_LOW_DevilsFee_Helsik_299a1c00-ff53-415e-ad8e-9bcbbae55597.

PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_8.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_8.text: A fake devil head? A lot of effort for a piece of window dressing.

PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_5.speaker: Karlach
PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_5.text: This is real. A Death Devil skull, by my reckoning.

PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_10.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_10.text: This head's a long way from home. Belongs to one of the Fugue Plane's death devils.

PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_11.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_02Skull_11.text: Only a true diabolist would have such an infernal collection.

SwD_Helsik_16.speaker: Narrator
SwD_Helsik_16.text: *The corpse does not stir. It will answer no more questions.*

SwD_Helsik_17.speaker: Narrator
SwD_Helsik_17.context: InternalNodeContext: Branch if Helsik dies because Raphael kill her after the alarm at House of Hope.

SwD_Helsik_10.speaker: Player
SwD_Helsik_10.text: What did Gortash pay you to do?

SwD_Helsik_0.speaker: Player
SwD_Helsik_0.text: What is the book you carry?

SwD_Helsik_5.speaker: Player
SwD_Helsik_5.text: How do I do the grimoire's ritual?

SwD_Helsik_4.speaker: Player
SwD_Helsik_4.text: Do you know what Raphael is guarding in his House?

SwD_Helsik_2.speaker: Narrator
SwD_Helsik_2.text: *The corpse remains silent. It does not know.*

SwD_Helsik_20.speaker: Narrator
SwD_Helsik_20.text: *The spell's power wanes. You can ask no more questions.*

SwD_Helsik_22.speaker: Narrator
SwD_Helsik_22.text: *The corpse seems willing to speak - but not to its killer.*

EmperorAD_FinishingRitual_0.text: There is nothing to be gained by invading the devil's home, and everything to be lost.

EmperorAD_FinishingRitual_1.text: Signing the devil's contract was an impulsive error. Do not seek to correct one mistake with another.

EmperorAD_FinishingRitual_2.text: You were wise to reject the devil's offer, but there is no reason to provoke him by invading his home.

AD_PatrolInOrder_0.speaker: Helsik
AD_PatrolInOrder_0.context: NodeContext: clipped but satisfied on the "just so"

PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_8.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_8.text: Never seen a gem like this - bet it's a fake.

PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_0.speaker: Karlach
PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_0.text: These are real hellish gems. Some of Minauros' hoard.

PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_11.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_11.text: Infernal gems, straight from the heart of Minauros. Quite the rarity.

PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_5.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_03Gems_5.text: Must be a diabolist running this shop with so many devillish artefacts.

PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_6.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_6.text: The horns of a real war devil. Bet they were a pain to acquire.

PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_7.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_7.text: So many authentic devillish items - a diabolist's at work here.

PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_11.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_11.text: Imitation horns, but barely distinguishable from the real thing.

PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_9.speaker: Karlach
PAD_HellishItems_04Horns_9.text: Holy shit, they're real. Torn from a war devil's skull.

EmperorAD_EnterRitualChamber_0.text: I strongly suggest that you reconsider this course of action.

EmperorAD_EnterRitualChamber_1.text: Whatever you expect to gain from the hells is not worth the risk of travelling there uninvited.

PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_4.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_4.text: A real fiend's skull... By the size, I'm guessing a ghargatula.

PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_6.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_6.text: So many infernal items... Looks like a genuine diabolist's collection.

PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_7.speaker: Player
PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_7.text: A replica devilish skull. Impressive, if a little out of place.

PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_11.speaker: Karlach
PAD_HellishItems_Bones01_11.text: 'Fraid that's the genuine article. From a ghargatula no doubt - big bastards.

PAD_FirstSeeCircleInvocation_0.speaker: Player
PAD_FirstSeeCircleInvocation_0.text: Hm. What was she trying to summon?

PAD_ItemsInInvocationRoom_0.speaker: Player
PAD_ItemsInInvocationRoom_0.text: Hm. What sort of 'curio shop' has authentic infernal objects?

Helsik_32.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_32.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee, where every hellish curio is a - Oh. It's you.

Helsik_69.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_69.text: Your little scrote of a friend left this on my floor the last time you visited.
Helsik_69.context: CinematicNodeContext: Helsik gives you Scleritas' hat. The DU takes it, non-plussed

Helsik_299.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_299.text: I presume you have returned to re-engage my services?

Helsik_133.speaker: Player
Helsik_133.text: I've never met you in my life.

Helsik_111.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_111.text: You... forgot what we did? I find that hard to believe.

Helsik_103.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_103.text: But, if you speak truth, perhaps I could... Jog that lazy memory of yours?

Helsik_322.speaker: Player
Helsik_322.text: My memory is quite beyond hope, don't bother.

Helsik_135.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_135.text: Very well. How else may I be of service?

Helsik_278.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_278.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee - That's the spiel I give the more mundane customers.

Helsik_55.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_55.text: It's a front, really. I sell tacky, devil-shaped knick-knacks to plebians, and a more... refined set of wares to discerning customers. Like yourself.

Helsik_137.speaker: Player
Helsik_137.text: Shit, this again. Remind me of our past association?

Helsik_205.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_205.text: I am afraid that I cannot take you back to Mephistopheles' vaults. That place is now locked tighter than Lord Mammon's coinpurse.

Helsik_25.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_25.text: I have, however, recently found a delightful new place I could sneak you into. Tell me, what do you know of the devil Raphael?

Helsik_60.speaker: Player
Helsik_60.text: Bring him the Crown of Karsus, or he shall sup on my soul. Etc. Etc.

Helsik_276.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_276.text: Ah, so you and Raphael have chatted recently? How... unusual.

Helsik_128.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_128.text: You remember the Crown of Karsus, yes?

Helsik_250.speaker: Player
Helsik_250.text: My wizard has spoken of little else, of late.

Helsik_48.speaker: Player
Helsik_48.text: I've heard of it - seems like everyone is after this crown.

Helsik_43.speaker: Player
Helsik_43.text: Why not? Let's say I do.

Helsik_240.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_240.text: I should hope so - last time you and Lord Gortash were here I charged you both a pretty penny to help steal it.

Helsik_199.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_199.text: I do enjoy a good tangent. I have found a way to slip the latch to his house, if you wish to leap into Avernus one more time. The crown seemed to interest you after all.

Helsik_28.speaker: Player
Helsik_28.text: Raphael must have all kinds of secrets in his House, and I want to undress them.

Helsik_184.speaker: Player
Helsik_184.text: Break into the House? If we were found, I doubt we'd come back.

Helsik_33.speaker: Player
Helsik_33.text: If I managed it before, I can pull it off again.

Helsik_291.speaker: Player
Helsik_291.text: I've forgotten every single thing I've ever done before a few tendays ago.

Helsik_316.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_316.text: You... don't recall? Odd. I refer to the Crown of Karsus you and Lord Enver Gortash stole from Avernus with my help. The devil Raphael desires it.

Helsik_169.speaker: Player
Helsik_169.text: Not as much as I'd like.

Helsik_223.speaker: Player
Helsik_223.text: Ah. Him again. Why is it always him?

Helsik_39.speaker: Player
Helsik_39.text: Your wares! Bring them before me!

Helsik_187.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_187.text: My most perceptive prospective customer... Welcome back.

Helsik_182.speaker: Player
Helsik_182.text: With regards to the House of Hope...

Helsik_132.speaker: Player
Helsik_132.text: Can you break me into the House of Hope?

Helsik_102.speaker: Player
Helsik_102.text: We have unfinished business - let's continue where we left off.

Helsik_16.speaker: Player
Helsik_16.text: I want more information about your business with Gortash.

Helsik_325.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_325.text: Well, I'm loathe to fully repeat myself... so I'll give you the whole tale. For a price, of course. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_3_01f129ea-b4dc-44b6-8154-9a948f876a82])

Helsik_84.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_84.text: Did I threaten you? Did I force the coin from your purse to mine? No. Pay up. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_3_01f129ea-b4dc-44b6-8154-9a948f876a82])

Helsik_155.speaker: Player
Helsik_155.text: Never mind. Just show me your wares.

Helsik_97.speaker: Player
Helsik_97.text: No, you're not getting more of my money.

Helsik_85.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_85.text: Then you'll hear no more of my tale.

Helsik_180.speaker: Player
Helsik_180.text: I want to know about Gortash's dealings in the hells.

Helsik_158.speaker: Player
Helsik_158.text: I have the money. Show me how to get to the House of Hope. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54]g)

Helsik_61.speaker: Player
Helsik_61.text: I have the money. Show me how to get to the House of Hope. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

Helsik_31.speaker: Player
Helsik_31.text: Show me your wares. The good stuff.

Helsik_208.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_208.text: Trips to the hells are usually one-way. Especially when the traveller causes the kind of trouble you did.

Helsik_123.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_123.text: I knew you were a thief. Didn't realise you were a killer.

Helsik_270.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_270.text: Raphael's death is already causing quite a stir across the hells - it's a rare thing for a mortal to slay a devil of his stature.

Helsik_72.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_72.text: In all the excitement, I hope you didn't forget our bargain. Do you have the Gauntlets?

Helsik_59.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_59.text: Hand them over, and our deal is done.

Helsik_154.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_154.text: That can be arranged. If there's enough coin on the table, Mammon permits almost anything.

Helsik_354.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_354.text: A handsome fee. The Gauntlets are yours to keep.

Helsik_174.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_174.text: There's nothing Mammon likes less than a welcher. Get the hell out and never come back.

Helsik_338.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_338.text: Then we have reached the end of our negotiations.

Helsik_323.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_323.text: Your coin is always welcome here, and so are you, devil-slayer.

Helsik_211.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_211.text: Is this a joke? You can't give me what you don't have.

Helsik_360.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_360.text: That invalidates our deal, I'm afraid. I fulfilled my part of the bargain, so you owe me the fee I proposed initially.

Helsik_67.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_67.text: I can see why your acquaintance with Raphael ended so violently - you're not a very convincing liar.

Helsik_19.speaker: Player
Helsik_19.text: Everything I took from the House is mine.

Helsik_255.speaker: Player
Helsik_255.text: I just killed a devil in his own home. You really don't want to test my patience.

Helsik_8.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_8.text: Not a subtle point, but well made. Keep the Gauntlets. Your threats aren't necessary, but your coin is still welcome, devil-slayer.

Helsik_340.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_340.text: That doesn't make you dangerous, it makes you a liability. Get out of here before you test my patience.

Helsik_40.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_40.text: I'm impressed. And just a little bit intimidated.

Helsik_209.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_209.text: I welcome thee to the Devil's Fee, where every hellish curio's a rarity! So merry be - and shop with glee.

Helsik_178.speaker: Karlach
Helsik_178.text: Oh no - definitely something up with this one. Trust me.
Helsik_178.context: NodeContext: Karlach has a bad feeling about a very chipper shopkeeper (and she's right).

Helsik_44.speaker: Narrator
Helsik_44.text: *Raphael's warlock, Korrilla, mentioned a diabolist who aided Gortash. This cheerful woman doesn't seem the likeliest candidate.*

Helsik_365.speaker: Player
Helsik_365.text: Curios don't interest me. I'm interested in the hells themselves - a place called the House of Hope in particular.

Helsik_3.speaker: Player
Helsik_3.text: Ever met an orthon? I have - he told me you're a diabolist.

Helsik_282.speaker: Player
Helsik_282.text: Can you get me into the House of Hope?

Helsik_257.speaker: Player
Helsik_257.text: Raphael told me the Crown of Karsus was stolen from Mephistopheles - were you involved with that?

Helsik_14.speaker: Player
Helsik_14.text: Did you help Lord Gortash retrieve some hellish curios by any chance?

Helsik_213.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_213.text: You must be awfully familiar with our esteemed Archduke to know about a thing like that.

Helsik_363.speaker: Player
Helsik_363.text: I know you're a diabolist who worked for Gortash. What did you do for him?

Helsik_277.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_277.text: Interesting. How exactly are you and our esteemed Archduke acquainted?

Helsik_119.speaker: Player
Helsik_119.text: I happened upon some of his correspondence that mentioned you dealings with him.
Helsik_119.context: InternalNodeContext: We can learn this by reading the reports from Ninefingers or her necromancy book.

Helsik_80.speaker: Player
Helsik_80.text: I'm intimately familiar with the lining of his pockets.

Helsik_37.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_37.text: Truly. That's remarkable. I like to deal with remarkable people. Very well.

Helsik_284.speaker: Player
Helsik_284.text: It's your acquaintance with him I'm interested in - I found his name in your ledger.

Helsik_20.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_20.text: Likewise. Well, less of a colleague, more of a contractor - but I digress.

Helsik_108.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_108.text: You seek answers, Lord Mammon seeks coin. I will happily mediate - make me an offer.

Helsik_12.speaker: Karlach
Helsik_12.text: Mammon! I knew it. I did!
Helsik_12.context: NodeContext: She already mentioned she had a bad feeling about this lady. Turns out she was right - she serves a devil called Mammon. Karlach isn't pleased about this but is glad she was right. Slightly comic, like she's expecting someone to challenge the fact that she knew it was Mammon (like saying 'I knew it!' after hearing an answer on jeopardy).

Helsik_189.speaker: Player
Helsik_189.text: Toss a coin to the diabolist.

Helsik_349.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_349.text: Ahah. Ahah. Ahah. Quite the fitting token. Let it not be said that Lord Mammon's servant does not deal with paupers.

Helsik_74.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_74.text: But I'm afraid you'll need to offer an awful lot more than that. I'll be keeping the coin, though, of course.

Helsik_275.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_275.text: Hmmm... The King of Avarice accepts your humble offering.

Helsik_58.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_58.text: A generous donation... The King of Avarice's pockets are most pleased.

Helsik_233.speaker: Player
Helsik_233.text: Actually I'll just take a look at your usual wares, if you don't mind.

Helsik_292.speaker: Player
Helsik_292.text: It's customary for any salesperson to offer a free sample.

Helsik_202.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_202.text: The first hit's free, eh? Fine - I'll humour you, mortal. Just this once.

Helsik_324.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_324.text: You stand before Mammon's Picklock. Latchkeeper of the Nine Hells. My business is not information, nor hellish curios, not really.

Helsik_311.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_311.text: I break people into the Hells. That's my thing.

Helsik_134.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_134.text: I can reveal to you that I opened a portal for Lord Gortash.

Helsik_18.speaker: Player
Helsik_18.text: Where in the hells did the portal go?

Helsik_65.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_65.text: My word... This is embarrassing. Perhaps I should have explained our terms better.

Helsik_10.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_10.text: You asked what I did for Lord Gortash, you paid the fee, and I answered you. Our pact is complete. Would you like to make another transaction?

Helsik_230.speaker: Player
Helsik_230.text: How much to tell me everything about your dealings with Gortash?

Helsik_227.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_227.text: Adjusting for inflation, the appreciable value of knowledge, Lord Mammon's tithe... A-ha. There we are. ([LOW_DevilsFee_GortashInfoPayment_4feace82-e2ce-a19d-967c-2a346b2cf96d])

Helsik_2.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_2.text: That 'something' was the inimitable Crown of Karsus. Gortash absconded with it - catching the interest of a devil named Raphael.

Helsik_7.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_7.text: Then to piecemeal information we return. You wish for more knowledge, make me an offer.

Helsik_129.speaker: Player
Helsik_129.text: Toss a single coin to the diabolist.

Helsik_344.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_344.text: Now now. That would be but a drop in Mammon's oceanic coffers - you can do better.

Helsik_343.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_343.text: Oh yes, I should think that'll do deliciously.

Helsik_352.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_352.text: Lord Gortash wanted to steal something from Mephistopheles, so I punched a portal into the Archdevil's dusty vaults.

Helsik_207.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_207.text: And then I... Gosh, my fickle memory fails. If only something would jog it.
Helsik_207.context: CinematicNodeContext: Helisik puts out their hand,

Helsik_327.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_327.text: I mean... I suppose that'll do. Stingy bastard.

Helsik_310.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_310.text: Yes, you are quite correct. The Crown of Karsus left the Vault, and an opportunity opened for a devil named Raphael.

Helsik_267.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_267.text: Gortash stole the Crown of Karsus. Pissed off Mephistopheles, but rather intrigued another devil by the name Raphael.

Helsik_300.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_300.text: You rascals stole the Crown of Karsus. Pissed off Mephistopheles to no end. I expect you'll pay the price for that one day.

Helsik_190.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_190.text: You also attracted the attention of another devil: Raphael.

Helsik_272.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_272.text: His House of Hope is furnished with a great deal of treasures, many related to Karsus. But alas, he lacks the crown itself.

Helsik_297.speaker: Narrator
Helsik_297.text: *The Crown of Karsus? If the diabolist is to be believed, this would be no ordinary Netherese relic. It could command the power of the gods themselves. Or the Hells, if Raphael gets hold of it.*

Helsik_104.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_104.text: He's rather ambitious. One can only wonder what he has planned for the Crown. The answers to that can probably be found within his house...

Helsik_191.speaker: Karlach
Helsik_191.text: Let's poke around the rat's nest. Maybe set it on fire on the way out.

Helsik_204.speaker: Lae'zel
Helsik_204.text: Looks like we owe Raphael a semi-friendly visit.

Helsik_286.speaker: Shadowheart
Helsik_286.text: Perhaps it's time we paid Raphael a visit.

Helsik_334.speaker: Astarion
Helsik_334.text: Then perhaps we should drop by and surprise Raphael? It'd make a nice change.

Helsik_220.speaker: Wyll
Helsik_220.text: Looks like we owe Raphael a housecall.

Helsik_302.speaker: Gale
Helsik_302.text: I think it's about time we imposed ourselves on Raphael's hospitality for a change.

Helsik_350.speaker: Halsin
Helsik_350.text: Then to Raphael's house we must go.

Helsik_83.speaker: Jaheira
Helsik_83.text: Time for a social call, then. I'm sure Raphael makes for a wonderful host.

Helsik_122.speaker: Player
Helsik_122.text: Can you help me break into the House of Hope?

Helsik_260.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_260.text: What a fascinating proposition. Ludicrous, of course, but fascinating nevertheless.

Helsik_162.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_162.text: Very well. If you wish to die in Avernus, that's your business. Mine is charging you for it.

Helsik_252.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_252.text: Of course, such a task will require quite the substantial donation to Lord Mammon's coffers. ([LOW_DevilsFee_ExpensiveHoH_b64a3173-46d0-e663-eaf6-ee900355256d])

Helsik_229.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_229.text: Such a task would be tantamount to suicide. Do not even entertain it.

Helsik_161.text: Such a task would be tantamount to suicide. And for what? The devil has nothing that you need.

Helsik_315.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_315.text: Why... The risk almost seems worth it when there's such pretty coins involved.
Helsik_315.context: NodeContext: they get distracted, enamoured by the gold, almost wistful

Helsik_86.speaker: Player
Helsik_86.text: I don't have that much money.

Helsik_171.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_171.text: Then get out of my sight - and don't come back until your pockets drag with gold.
Helsik_171.context: NodeContext: deeply insulted by the player's cheek

Helsik_285.speaker: Player
Helsik_285.text: I don't have that much money.

Helsik_253.speaker: Player
Helsik_253.text: Waive the fee and I'll add one of Raphael's artefacts to your collection.

Helsik_218.speaker: Player
Helsik_218.text: I'm a skilled thief - give me free passage I'll bring you back a 'souvenir'.

Helsik_96.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_96.text: You put me in a difficult position, mortal.

Helsik_232.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_232.text: You are almost certain to fail. Almost. And so, there is a chance you might succeed.

Helsik_326.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_326.text: Fine. I'd like to be able to carry all of my precious stock without the need of a team of oxen.

Helsik_120.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_120.text: There are Gauntlets of Hill Giant Strength within the House of Hope. Free passage, and you fetch them for me. Deal?

Helsik_321.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_321.text: Allow me to outline how this is going to work.

Helsik_356.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_356.text: First, you were never here. We never spoke.

Helsik_268.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_268.text: Second. You will perform the rites yourself - I want absolute deniability. Here's the grimoire and necessary components.
Helsik_268.context: NodeContext: helsik returns to a more serious mode of address here

Helsik_342.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_342.text: Take this key, too. It unlocks the ritual room upstairs. There's a blood circle already drawn. Don't ask whose blood.

Helsik_328.speaker: Narrator
Helsik_328.text: *Along with the grimoire and components, Helsik hands you a note containing precise instructions for performing the ritual.*

Helsik_21.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_21.text: Finally, you were never here. That is of utmost import to remember. Now - begone.

Helsik_82.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_82.text: Very well. Here is the... What? I couldn't have misplaced... I've been robbed.

Helsik_62.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_62.text: OUT! The shop is closed. You and everyone else can go to hell - WITHOUT my help.

Helsik_274.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_274.text: My time is money, and you've wasted too much of it. Get out of my sight.

Helsik_304.speaker: Player
Helsik_304.text: You'll halve that price or I'll halve you.

Helsik_51.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_51.text: Far be it from me to overlook reason, reflected in the edge of a blade.

Helsik_121.speaker: Player
Helsik_121.text: Cut the price or I cut you into little pieces. CHOOSE.

Helsik_318.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_318.text: Let me tell you what happens if Raphael even suspects I'm poking around his home.

Helsik_301.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_301.text: I'll be scattered across the Hells like a broken snuffbox. The price stays. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Helsik_170.speaker: Player
Helsik_170.text: Look, we both know your patron doesn't need that much. Lower the price.

Helsik_228.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_228.text: For a fellow diabolist? I can stoop lower. Once.

Helsik_243.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_243.text: I will grant a discount - a final discount, mind you. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_2_463b0f43-5410-412d-aba3-875cf81c38ca])

Helsik_305.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_305.text: Who died and made you the expert on Mammon's expectant pockets? I certainly didn't. The price stays. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Helsik_127.speaker: Player
Helsik_127.text: I already paid you too much. You are ripping me off.

Helsik_320.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_320.text: Correction dear. Lord Mammon is ripping you off. It's sort of his thing.

Helsik_164.speaker: Player
Helsik_164.text: That's a steep sum - I need some time to mull this over.

Helsik_166.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_166.text: Mull, or don't mull. It matters not to me. If you have coin, return. If not - don't.

Helsik_361.speaker: Player
Helsik_361.text: Well, that was interesting, but I'd just like to see your wares.

Helsik_77.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_77.text: Now you've seen what I have for thee - remember, discretion is key at the Devil's Fee.

Helsik_195.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_195.text: Coin and time most fortuitously spent.

Helsik_46.speaker: Player
Helsik_46.text: That information wasn't worth what I paid.

Helsik_5.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_5.text: And yet you paid anyway. What a terrible cosmic coincidence.

Helsik_346.speaker: Minsc
Helsik_346.text: Then I shall brush out Boo's fur - for we are going a-visiting.
Helsik_346.context: NodeContext: You've been told that the secret to this whole conspiracy lies in a devil's residence - you're not even questioning tha that's where you're going next.

Helsik_115.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
Helsik_115.text: We should infiltrate the devil's home. I have always dreamed of visiting the hells.

Helsik_280.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_280.text: My, what deep pockets you have.

Helsik_298.speaker: Player
Helsik_298.text: My offer is - let me be a regular customer. I'd like to trade.

Helsik_124.speaker: Player
Helsik_124.text: Let's keep this simple. I'd just like to trade.

Helsik_56.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_56.text: I could remind you that you sought me, not vice versa. But why would I. I shall leave you in your blissful ignorance.

Helsik_221.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_221.text: Well, adjusting for inflation... appreciable value of knowledge but factoring in a dead-as-doornails Archduke... There we are. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_7_4f22f91f-28ec-8f22-c546-1f8b69a2725a])

Helsik_144.speaker: Player
Helsik_144.text: Perhaps a more banal transaction. May I see your wares?

Helsik_266.speaker: Player
Helsik_266.text: What business did Gortash have in the Hells?

Helsik_13.speaker: Player
Helsik_13.text: Raphael told me the Crown of Karsus was stolen from Mephistopheles - were you involved with that?

Helsik_151.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_151.text: Ra-pha-el? That sounds vaguely familiar, but I have a terrible memory for names. The only thing that jogs it is coin.
Helsik_151.context: NodeContext: Sounding out the syllables of Raphael individually as if trying to remember if she's heard the name before, in an exaggerated performative manner

Helsik_175.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_175.text: There's no fun in that - so I think not. Make an offer, mortal.

Helsik_341.speaker: Player
Helsik_341.text: You know, any saleswoman worth her salt offers a free sample.

Helsik_64.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_64.text: Ah how cute. You tried that last time too.

Helsik_139.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_139.text: You want answers, you pay. Just like everyone else. Mammon is nothing if not egalitarian.

Helsik_251.speaker: Player
Helsik_251.text: Material wealth is a vain illusion. If you seek meaning and purpose, try compassion - give us a hint.

Helsik_94.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_94.text: You're telling me wealth is an illusion? What part of 'Mammon worshipper' do you not understand?

Helsik_160.speaker: Player
Helsik_160.text: Coin will do your corpse no good. SPEAK.

Helsik_117.speaker: Player
Helsik_117.text: I'm also of the pact-bound persuasion - don't suppose I can have a free sample?

Helsik_163.speaker: Player
Helsik_163.text: I'm something of a diabolist myself - perhaps you could spare a little free knowledge?

Helsik_196.speaker: Player
Helsik_196.text: We were lovers. It was all very steamy.

Helsik_73.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_73.text: My, what a juicy morsel. I didn't think he liked your type. Anyway...

Helsik_214.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_214.text: My my... touchy subject I see. Very well.

Helsik_107.speaker: Player
Helsik_107.text: Your hoard of genuine infernal items is impressive - show me the really good stuff.

Helsik_347.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_347.text: Well well - it's been a while since I've had such discerning custom. Here, you may browse my more... curated selection.

Helsik_168.speaker: Player
Helsik_168.text: Let's see what you've got on offer.

Helsik_262.speaker: Player
Helsik_262.text: I found some interesting reading material downstairs. You're a diabolist, it seems.

Helsik_210.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_210.text: Begone. The Devil's Fee is closed for business.

Helsik_303.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_303.text: My apologies, your eminentness, but the Devil's Fee is closed for business.

Helsik_312.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_312.text: I can feel the heat from that portal all the way down here. Keep it open as long as you need, but be sure nothing follows you through.

Helsik_319.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_319.text: Need anything before you head back to the hells?

Helsik_71.speaker: Player
Helsik_71.text: I've got a pair of gauntlets for you - still warm from Raphael's vault.

Helsik_314.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_314.text: Welcome back, devil-slayer. What can I do for you?

Helsik_336.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_336.text: How may I be of further assistance?

Helsik_339.speaker: Helsik
Helsik_339.text: Your esteemedness returns! O joyous hour.

PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee_0.speaker: Player
PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee_0.text: The Devil's Fee'. What do they sell, souls?

PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee_2.speaker: Player
PAD_ArrivingDevilsFee_2.text: I wouldn't take it too seriously - it's probably just here to part gullible travellers and their coin.

RitualCircle_0.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches the blood circle, grimoire open. Any other party member stands behind them. The player finishes reading the last line, muttering its contents to themselves, and closes it. Ideally we have low infernal music to cover the need for any player lines.

RitualCircle_7.context: InternalNodeContext: Checking if we have the infernal marble.

RitualCircle_8.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player reaches their arm out, palm outstretched, over the ritual circle. The infernal marble is in it. It begins to glow, and the entire room around it darkens. As the player closes their fist around the infernal marble, we see them from above, and the the blood underneath the player's closed fist lights ablaze, tracing around the ritual circle's outline in fire. The player drops the infernal marble, and the floor within the blazing outline ripples, We are no longer seeing a wooden floor, we see the crackling sky of Avernus.

RitualCircle_2.speaker: Narrator
RitualCircle_2.text: *As you approach the ritual circle, you feel the warm crackle of Avernus' flame across your skin.*
RitualCircle_2.context: CinematicNodeContext: We see the player, the fire flicking shadows against them açs they stare into the portal.

RitualCircle_9.speaker: Portal to the House of Hope
RitualCircle_9.text: Signing the devil's contract was an impulsive error. Do not seek to correct one mistake with another.

RitualCircle_6.speaker: Portal to the House of Hope
RitualCircle_6.text: You were wise to reject the devil's offer, but there is no reason to provoke him by invading his home.

RitualCircle_3.text: There is nothing to be gained by invading the devil's home, and everything to be lost.

RitualCircle_4.context: CinematicNodeContext: Again, shot from above: The other party members gather around the circle's edge. The party takes one step together into the blazing circle. A rush of fire engulfs the group. When it clears, they are gone, only the portal to avernus remains, fiery symbol still glowing atop the Avernus skyscape.

RitualCircle_1.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player reaches their arm out, palm outstretched, over the ritual circle. Player doesn't have the infernal marble. Nothing happens.InternalNodeContext: Maybe we can have a little bit of humour here.

RitualCircle_5.speaker: Narrator
RitualCircle_5.text: *You feel a thrum across your palm, warm, longing. The ritual requires a component you seem to lack.*
RitualCircle_5.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player looks at their hand, confused.

AD_PatrolNotInOrder_0.speaker: Helsik
AD_PatrolNotInOrder_0.text: Something... taken. Stolen. Oh, that will not do.
AD_PatrolNotInOrder_0.context: NodeContext: growing, roiling anger at the end
